text: hi everyone Crampton ii test anno here
the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of the new absol
record these days this guy is a West
Coast emcees been lighting up my ears
with his lyrics ever since he dropped
that AB soul interlude on Kendrick
Lamar's fantastic album section.80
I went on to love the album he dropped
in 2012 control system one of my
favorite hip-hop records of that year
and on this record he gave himself the
label the abstract [ __ ] and it is a
name that he has lived up to with his
brags with his drug talk with his foul
mouth but simultaneously his lions are
loaded with incredible wordplay and
references that are biological
philosophical biblical so of course
there was no reason whatsoever not to be
looking forward to whatever he was doing
down the road certainly a man who would
craft a track such as terrorist threats
has nothing mild in his future but that
in fact seems to be the case with these
days to me this record is the sound of
an adventurous emcee doing a 180 and
trying to write a more commercial record
which in theory isn't a bad thing
but the thing is writing catchy music
comes with its own league of
difficulties and challenges challenges
are not really sure absol is up to
facing four years for project after
project absol has put together some
pretty smart conscious out their
creative hip-hop music and to totally
switch around and try to write more
straightforward in-your-face earworm
type stuff he's essentially walking a
different walk on this record and I
think the end result is pretty
middle-of-the-road
now do not get me wrong absol is not
writing totally ignorant Mego style
verses on this thing but it's rare that
he comes through with the mind-expanding
set of bars like the third verse on the
track Tree of Life one of the best
verses on this entire record I
especially love the ending line talking
about why money is green because it's
like vegetation the most important of
all things his verses on the opening
track here are pretty thoughtful on the
opening verse to the song stigmata one
of the better tracks on this thing as
well and there are
some lines that stick out on the Rick
Ross featured song never mind that where
he's saying you're a librarian got room
for my dick ssin airy it's not great but
he's trying although there is kind of an
interesting thing going on with this
track absol is opening verse on this
song which is one of the deeper and more
interesting verses on this entire thing
is interrupted by this really short shot
of what sounds like TV or radio
Distortion and then it quickly goes into
this R&B chorus saying never mind that
never mind that it's almost as if this
track or maybe this entire record in
general is absolute at writing poppier
simpler more straightforward music as
some kind of common on not saying
anything substantial it's a concept I
can get down with in theory but in
execution musically for a loud trap
flavored hip-hop song this is pretty
terrible the pacing of the instrumental
is way too slow and this track is just
so cluttered with the pitched vocals
with Rick Ross's feature with AB souls
versus with the R&B singing the constant
shots of distortion changing the song
from one flavor to another the guitar
line weaved into the beat as well the
song just has so many different things
going on most of the time on this record
absol isn't really delivering awful
lyrics as much as he is just in my
opinion delivering lyrics that I think
are subpar for him not really thoughtful
or thought-provoking stuff namely on
tracks like hunted Stax a song featuring
schoolboy q and I don't mind schoolboy q
I liked his last record but schoolboy
might as well have been rapping across
this entire track because topically
there's nothing really separating AB and
schoolboy I mean they use the exact same
flow throughout the entire track there
are other tracks on here where the hooks
are especially weak and just really
incessant really redundant like dub sack
and feeling us
there's the song tracked off this thing
which has a Atlantis snap beat
instrumental riding in the background
the whole song feels like he heard a
single off of that new yg record and
then hit the studio the only catch
etrack that I think was legitimately
good on this entire record was just have
fun really upbeat bright instrumental
I feel like abs voice definitely brings
a positive feel-good vibe across as well
there's a slight commentary on using
drugs not allowing drugs to use you in
the opening refrain it's a pretty
lackluster first half of the record but
the second half is I'm not going to say
good but very turbulent and surprising
namely with the Kendrick Lamar featured
song on here where essentially Kendrick
is doing with a jazz instrumental
hanging in the background exactly what
absol did for him on section 80 and of
course emotionally it's intense its
lyrically OnPoint
the instrumental is amazing Kendrick
Lamar's energies through the roof it's
kind of the best track on the entire
record
there's also tracks on the back end of
this thing like closure which is this
terrible sad sack song where I don't
really mind a bit of heartbreak or a bit
of a story about a relationship on the
rocks but absol is singing very weakly
throughout this entire track and it just
gets really tedious and dull quickly the
closing track on this LP not a bad song
one of the lyrically tighter tracks on
this entire thing and there is a kid
cudi like hook on this thing except I do
enjoy it but this closing track what
makes it so strange that it comes with
an amazing surprise as soon as this song
concludes and that is what seems to be
raw audio of a battle a rap battle
between absol and daylight with a crowd
of people there listening to them there
are a few points where it's pretty
audible that Schoolboy Q is there AB
does a verse daylight does a verse this
lasts for almost 20 minutes
and it's so thrilling and it's so
interesting because absol for a guy who
doesn't battle professionally really
holds his own for whatever reason you
put this thing on the record I think
it's a great addition I mean I feel like
there are a lot of people in hip-hop
fans of hip hop right now who complain
that there's a certain level of talent
lacking in a lot of the bigger artists
in the industry right now I hear you
have an artist coming forward putting
his reputation on the line battling
someone who's pretty notable in the
world of battle rap and even though
people seemed a little more impressed by
the time daylight was done
I prefer what AB did more I just wish
that more of that turned up on the
tracks earlier in this record you know
their songs on this thing that I love
songs on the thing that I hate there
were tracks that were completely out of
the blue moves that were totally
unexpected even though I feel at the end
of the day that I'm very on the fence
with this thing it's at least
interesting as an experience I have to
say that I'm feeling a strong five to a
light six on this thing transition if
you've given this thing a listen what
did you think of it did you love it
did you hate it why what do you think I
should review next and that's it
absol these days
solo forever
